Article Ultra-low doping 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts: Modulating the electronic states of active metal sites to enhance CO oxidation through high entropy strategy Yongqi Zhao a Junjie Jiang a Yang Zou a Pu Wang a Xue Li a Xiaolong Liu a b * Tingyu Zhu a a CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China CAS Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China b Key Laboratory of Green and High-value Utilization of Salt Lake Resources, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xining 810008, Ningxia, China Key Laboratory of Green and High-value Utilization of Salt Lake Resources Chinese Academy of Sciences Xining Ningxia 810008 China Key Laboratory of Green and High-value Utilization of Salt Lake Resources, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xining 810008, Ningxia, China * Corresponding author. The catalyst cost is a key factor limiting the CO purification of sintering flue gas. Here, an ultra-low-loading high-entropy catalyst was prepared by simple calcination process. By anchoring multiple active metal sites in the stable anatase TiO2 phase, it shows efficient CO catalytic oxidation activity. The metal components (Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were uniformly dispersed on the surface of TiO2 in the form of high-entropy compounds and undergo strong metal and support interaction with TiO2. The results showed that 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 achieved complete oxidation of CO at 230 °C, and its catalytic oxidation ability was significantly better than that of the corresponding monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. The high-entropy component adjusts the electronic environment between the TiO2 support and the metal to promote the reduction of the Ti3d band gap, enhances the electron-induced ability of the catalytic system to gas molecules (CO and O2), and exhibits excellent resistance to SO2 and H2O. The work is of great significance to understand the synergistic regulation of catalyst activity by multiple metal at the atomic level and provides a strategy for effectively reducing the content of precious metals in the catalyst. Graphical Abstract The ultra-low doping 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 high entropy catalyst with strong metal and support interaction (SMSI) to achieve efficient CO catalytic oxidation from sintering flue gas by activating the lattice oxygen species on the surface of TiO2. Keywords High-entropy catalysts Ultra-low doping CO oxidation Sintering flue gas Strong metal and support interaction 1 Introduction In the iron and steel production industry, the incomplete combustion of fuel results in the highest CO emissions during the sintering process, contributing to more than half of the total CO emissions across the entire steel sector [1–3]. The issue has emerged as a critical challenge in atmospheric environmental management. Consequently, there is an urgent requirement for the development of effective technologies to purify high concentrations of CO in flue gas. Catalytic oxidation technology has been identified as a promising method for CO purification in flue gases [4,5]. However, the complex composition and substantial volume of sintering flue gas pose challenges to the stability and cost-effectiveness of CO catalysts, thereby limiting the advancement of this technology [6,7]. Thus, the development of an economical and stable CO catalyst is of paramount importance for the sustainable development of the steel industry. In recent years, a substantial number of catalysts, including transition metal oxides such as cobalt (Co), copper (Cu), and manganese (Mn) [8–10], as well as noble metal oxides like gold (Au), platinum (Pt), and palladium (Pd), have demonstrated efficient catalytic capabilities for CO in flue gas [11–14]. Notably, noble metal catalysts have garnered significant scholarly attention due to their exceptional catalytic activity and resistance to poisoning. The unique d orbital structure of noble metal atoms, along with their central positioning, plays a crucial role in determining the adsorption strength of oxidation intermediates at the catalyst’s active sites, thereby significantly influencing the adsorption and conversion of CO [15–18]. Nonetheless, the high-performance catalysts currently available necessitate a considerable content of noble metals. For instance, Chen et al. [19] employed ultra-small Pd nanoparticles (1%) to coat TiO2, thereby enhancing the metal-support interaction (SMSI) and achieving efficient catalytic oxidation of CO under challenging conditions. Similarly, Zhou et al. [20] improved the strong interaction between Pt particles (2%) and anatase by exposing the high-energy TiO2 crystal plane (101), facilitating complete catalytic oxidation of CO at 120 °C. Therefore, how to effectively reduce the content of noble metal active components in the catalyst has become the focus of restricting the promotion of CO catalytic technology. Recently, high-entropy catalysts (HECs), which consist of five or more metallic elements, have garnered significant attention as heterogeneous catalytic components with promising potential due to their exceptional catalytic performance and coordination capabilities [21,22]. The synergistic interactions among the multiple metal constituents in HECs result in properties unattainable by individual metal components. Notably, the co-doping of non-noble and noble metals can optimize the d-band center and electronic structure of HECs, thereby maximizing the utilization of noble metal elements and activating the active sites of reactants on the catalyst surface [23]. HECs exhibit a synergistic effect of multi-metal components in the structure, forming a multi-active center through SMSI, thereby significantly improving the catalytic performance in terms of activity and durability. In addition, HECs have attracted more and more research attention because they can significantly reduce the use of precious metals and thus reduce the cost of catalysts [24,25]. Xu et al. [26] successfully synthesized ultra-low-load high-entropy catalytic materials using a quenching method. Various metal components are anchored on the surface of TiO2 in the form of complexes, which optimizes the electronic environment between the carrier and the active component, thereby facilitating the dissociation and migration of reactants on the catalyst surface. Dhakar et al. [27] synthesized a nanocrystalline high-entropy alloy catalyst (CoFeNiGaZn) for the catalytic oxidation of CO. The active nickel atom facilitates the electron transfer to O2, forming *O, which ultimately enhances the efficient adsorption and activation of CO. Nevertheless, there remains a lack of comprehensive understanding regarding the complete reaction pathway of CO reactants and intermediates on the HEC surface. Consequently, a deeper insight into the potential of HEC in the CO catalytic oxidation process, along with a clarification of the electronic local structure characteristics between the active constituents and the carrier, is anticipated to achieve both high catalytic activity and cost-effective catalytic material design. In this study, we synthesized a highly active ultra-low doping 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 high-entropy catalyst (0.1 wt%) using the calcination method and systematically evaluated its catalytic activity for CO oxidation and its stability against H2O/SO2 interference using a fixed-bed infrared reaction apparatus. The impact of high-entropy active components on the crystal structure of TiO2 was thoroughly analyzed employing high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman techniques. Furthermore, techniques such as H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR), O2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD), CO-TPD/TPR, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in-situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectroscopy (DRIFTs) were utilized to elucidate the active sites for CO and O2 adsorption and activation on the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 high-entropy catalyst surface. To further investigate the interaction between the adsorbed species and the catalyst surface, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to assess the adsorption energy of CO [28,29]. The work provides critical insights into the design of novel strategies and materials that selectively modulate the *CO and *O descriptors for active CO oxidation on high-entropy materials through the integration of multiple elements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Tetrabutyl titanate (C16H36O4Ti, AR, 99%), H2PtCl6 (AR, 8.0 wt%), Mn(NO3)2 (AR, 50.0 wt%), Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (AR, 99.0%), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (AR, 99.0%) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (AR, 99.0%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Firstly, TiO2 was prepared by hydrolysis of tetrabutyl titanate. The 42.61 g tetrabutyl titanate was placed in an eggplant-shaped flask, added with 300 mL deionized water, and mechanically stirred for 12 h to obtain solid Ti(OH)4. Furthermore, Ti(OH)4 was placed at 500 °C for 4 h, and finally obtained white TiO2. Next, equimolar (0.01 mmol) amounts of H2PtCl6, Mn(NO3)2, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 1.95 g of TiO2 were weighed and dissolved in 150 mL of deionized water. Subsequently. The mixed solution was rotated and dried at 60 °C and −0.1 MPa to obtain solid A, which was then transferred to a muffle furnace and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. Finally, a catalyst loaded with high-entropy active components was collected and named 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2. In the same step, the catalysts loaded with only Pt and loaded with two elements were named 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(PtM)/TiO2, respectively (M represents the second component). 2.3 Characterization The microstructure and physicochemical properties of 0.1Pt/TiO2, 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts were elucidated by using various characterization techniques. The HRTEM (JEM-F200) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was used to analyze the microstructure and element distribution of the catalyst. XRD (Empyrean, 5°−95°) and Raman spectroscopy (iHR550 Horiba) was used to test the crystal structure and chemical composition of the catalyst. XPS (AXIS SUPRA+) was used to explore the binding energies (BE) of Ti, O, Pt, Mn, Fe, Co and Ni, and the BE was aligned basing on standard C 1s at 284.8 eV. H2/CO-TPR experiments were conducted using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer. In each H2/CO-TPR experiment, 100 mg of catalyst was placed in the reaction tube and subjected to pretreatment with pure argon (Ar) at a flow rate of 50 mL/min at 500 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, upon cooling the sample to 50 °C, the atmosphere was switched to a 10% H2/Ar (or 10% CO/Ar) mixture at a flow rate of 50 mL/min. The temperature was then increased to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, while the consumption of H2/CO was continuously monitored using a thermal conductivity detector. CO/O2-TPD analysis of the catalysts was conducted using BRUKER-INVENIOs. The samples (100 mg) were pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h in a N2 atmosphere. Once cooled to 50 °C, they were exposed to 5% CO/N2 (or 5% O2/N2) for 1 h to achieve adsorption saturation. Residual gas was purged with N2 for another h. The temperature was then ramped from 50 to 600 °C at 10 °C/min under N2. In-situ DRIFTS experiments were used to explore the conversion mechanism of CO on the catalyst surface using an online BRUKER-INVENIOs Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer in the range of 4000–1000 cm–1. To exclude the effects of moisture and impurities, the catalyst was pretreated at 400 °C under N2 atmosphere for 60 min before each test. Background spectra were collected by switching the temperature to the target temperature (275, 250, 225, 200, 175 °C). Then the gas was switched to 1% CO or 1% CO + 16% O2, the total flow rate was 200 mL/min, and the spectrum was collected after each temperature point was maintained for 30 min. The first-principles calculations were conducted to elucidate the mechanism using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The software employs the Projector Augmented-Wave (PAW) pseudopotential and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional within the framework of the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA). These methodologies were utilized to optimize the structural configurations and determine the free energy of all structures involved. For the adsorption energy calculations, a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 450 eV was employed. The electronic self-consistent field iterations were set to converge to within 10–5 eV, and the atomic positions were fully relaxed until the residual forces on each atom were reduced to below 0.02 eV/Å. Additionally, 15 Å vacuum layer was introduced along the z-direction to mitigate periodic interactions. The adsorption energy (E a, eV) was calculated using the following equation [30]: E a = E adsorb − (E sur + E gas) where E adsorb, E sur and E gas are the total energies of the adsorption system, catalyst surface and gases, respectively. 2.4 CO oxidation activity The catalytic efficacy of the catalyst for CO oxidation was evaluated using a fixed-bed infrared coupling platform. 0.2 g sample of the catalyst, sieved to a particle size of 40−60 mesh, was placed within a temperature–adjustable quartz reactor. The gas flow rate was maintained at 200 mL/min, corresponding to a space velocity of 60000 h−¹. The reaction gas mixture consisted of 10000 ppm CO, 16% O2, 10% water vapor (when applicable), 25 ppm SO2 (when applicable), with nitrogen serving as the balance gas. The composition and concentration of the effluent gases were continuously monitored using an online BRUKER-INVENIOs FT-IR spectrometer. The CO conversion efficiency was calculated by the following equation [31]: η CO = (COIn – COOut)/COIn × 100% where η CO is CO concentration efficiency, CO In is the inlet CO concentration, CO Out is the outlet CO concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical-structural characteristics of the catalysts The 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 and 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized using the hydrolysis method and the calcination precipitation method. The synthesis procedure for 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 is depicted in Fig. 1(a) . The approach of employing ultra-low loading (0.1 wt%) effectively facilitates the uniform dispersion of multiple active components on the TiO2 surface, resulting in the formation of highly dispersed high-entropy oxides. The nanostructure of the catalyst was further examined using HRTEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED). As illustrated in Figs. 1(b)–(d), the TiO2 substrate predominantly exhibits a polycrystalline anatase structure, characterized primarily by the (101) and (011) crystal planes, with corresponding lattice spacings of 0.356 and 0.258 nm, respectively. The results show a slight deviation from the reference values of 0.345 and 0.250 nm for the (101) and (011) crystal planes, respectively, which can be attributed to the co-dispersion of various active components within the TiO2 lattice. To further investigate the distribution of elements within the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst, EDS-mapping was employed. As depicted in Figs. 1(e)–(k), the signal intensities for all elements are observed in the same region, indicating that Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni are uniformly distributed and establish close contact with TiO2 at the nanoscale. The results indicate that the anatase TiO2 support facilitates the uniform dispersion of the ultra–low-loaded high entropy oxide active component on its surface, thereby restricting the migration of monodisperse active atoms and preventing agglomeration [32–34]. Furthermore, the TEM image of the 0.1(PtM)TiO2 catalyst, presented in Fig. S1, reveals that the elements Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni are uniformly distributed on the TiO2 surface, as evidenced by EDS-mapping. The distribution, with the exception of Ti and O elements, confirms the homogeneous integration of the various elements (Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ti, and O). XRD and Raman spectroscopy analyses have confirmed that anatase TiO2 is the sole crystalline phase present in all synthesized catalysts, as illustrated in Figs. S2 and S3. The XRD data (Fig. S2) indicate that the incorporation of various metals does not significantly influence the structural integrity or composition of TiO2. All supported TiO2 catalysts exhibit characteristic anatase peaks at 2θ values of 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.1°, 53.9°, and 62.9°, corresponding to the (101), (004), (200), (211), and (204) crystal planes, respectively [35]. Notably, the intensity of the peak associated with the (101) crystal plane is markedly higher than that of the others, suggesting that the predominant exposed surface of the synthesized TiO2 catalyst is the (101) plane. Raman spectroscopy further elucidated the structural vibrations and defect states of the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 and 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. S3, the bands at 156, 162, 398, 515, 638, and 162 cm–1 correspond to the Eg, B1g, and A1g+B1g vibrational modes within the TiO2 structure, respectively. It is noteworthy that the Eg bands of the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst exhibit a shift to a higher wavenumber (162 cm–1) in comparison to other catalysts (156 cm–1) [36]. This observation substantiates the incorporation of ultra-low-loading high-entropy alloy elements into TiO2 lattice. The significant red shift of the Eg dominant band (6 cm–1) suggests that the high-entropy elements enhance the interaction between TiO2 and the active components, thereby weakening the Ti–O bond and facilitating the formation of active oxygen vacancies [37]. 3.2 Chemical-structural characteristics of the catalysts The redox characteristics of catalysts are pivotal in determining their efficacy during the CO oxidation reaction, as evidenced by the H2-TPR profiles depicted in Fig. 2(a) . For the 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 samples, two distinct bands are observed at 150–200 and 410–425 °C, respectively. The peak within the 150–200 °C range primarily arises from the reduction of H2 by Pt2+ and Pt0. The incorporation of a secondary element results in varying degrees of peak shifts among different 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 catalysts compared to 0.1Pt/TiO2. The peak at 410–425 °C is associated with the consumption of H2 by the TiO2 support. Notably, the reduction peak of H2 on the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst exhibits a significant shift to lower temperatures (363.6, 257.6 °C), indicating a pronounced synergistic interaction among Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Ti, and O species. This interaction enhances the mobility of oxygen on the catalyst surface and increases the prevalence of oxygen defects. For the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst, a subtle reduction peak was observed at 111.2 °C, which can be ascribed to the reduction of Pt0 species [38]. Similarly, the reduction peak at 197.8 °C corresponds to the reduction of highly dispersed Pt2+ species. The findings suggest a robust chemical interaction between the high-entropy active component and the TiO2 support, which is likely to enhance electron transfer during the CO catalytic oxidation reaction [39]. To investigate the formation of active oxygen and the behavior of oxygen migration on the catalyst surface, O2-TPD experiments were performed to analyze the desorption behavior of oxygen species across all catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 2(b). In the O2-TPD spectra, the desorption peaks of oxygen species are categorized as follows: physically adsorbed oxygen (O2(ads), < 100 °C), peroxy species (O2–(ads), 100–250 °C), surface lattice oxygen species (O–(ads), 250–400 °C), and lattice oxygen (O2(lattice), > 400 °C). As shown in Fig. 2(b), the desorption peaks of lattice oxygen species are observed within the temperature ranges of 250–400 and above 400 °C for single-element Pt and dual-element (Pt–M) modified TiO2, respectively, indicating a limited oxygen adsorption capacity. In contrast, when five elements (Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) are concurrently doped into TiO2, the characteristic lattice oxygen desorption peak in the catalyst is no longer present. Instead, a new peroxide characteristic peak emerges at 171.7 °C, which suggests that the incorporation of high-entropy active components enhances the surface electronic structure of TiO2, facilitating the conversion of O2 into active dioxygen intermediates on the catalyst surface, thereby improving the catalyst’s ability to oxidize CO at low temperatures [40]. The CO-TPR experiment was employed to further investigate the complexity of the interaction between adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface and CO gas molecules. As shown in Fig. 2(c), all catalysts display three distinct characteristic peaks within the operational temperature range of 50–500 °C, specifically at 50–100, 100–150, and 250–350 °C. The peaks observed in the 50–100 °C range are primarily attributed to the consumption of physically adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface by CO. In contrast, the peaks in the 100–150 and 250–350 °C ranges correspond to the consumption of chemisorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, respectively. Notably, the peaks associated with the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst are shifted to lower temperatures across all temperature ranges when compared to other catalysts. This shift suggests that a unique charge interaction is established between the high–entropy active component and the TiO2 interface, facilitating a more efficient reaction with CO molecules [41]. To further evaluate the CO adsorption capacity of 0.1Pt/TiO2, 0.1(PtM)/TiO2, and the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts, CO-TPD tests were conducted to assess CO desorption. As displayed in Fig. 2(d), all catalysts exhibited strong CO adsorption within the temperature range of 50–500 °C. An increase in the desorption temperature of CO on the catalyst surface indicates a stronger interaction between the catalyst’s active component and the CO molecule. Notably, the high-entropy catalyst demonstrated complete CO desorption at temperatures exceeding 436.9 °C, suggesting that the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst possesses a superior CO adsorption capacity compared to the other catalysts. This enhancement not only increases the number of adsorption sites but also facilitates CO adsorption by the catalyst. Consequently, the high-entropy active components formed by various elements significantly enhance the catalyst’s intrinsic CO adsorption capacity, thereby improving its catalytic oxidation performance [39,42,43]. 3.3 Surface element characteristics All elements present in the 0.1Pt/TiO2, 0.1(PtM)/TiO2, and high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts were characterized using XPS spectra. The corresponding results are illustrated in Figs. 3–5 and Figs. S4–S8. It is noteworthy that the active components supported on all catalysts exhibit a low concentration (0.1 wt%). Despite conducting numerous detailed scans, only the valence states of Ti, O, and Pt were discernible, allowing for the assessment of the electron distribution on the TiO2 catalyst surface. As depicted in Fig. 3, the binding energies of Ti4+ (463.1 eV) and Ti3+ (462.2 eV) in the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst were observed to increase in the 0.1(PtM)/TiO2 catalyst upon the incorporation of a second active component. On the contrary, the binding energy of Ti4+ and Ti3+ in the Ti 2p orbital of the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst is negatively shifted to 462.9 and 462.0 eV, respectively, with a decay rate of 0.2 eV. The phenomenon indicates that the effect of high-entropy components on electron transfer is higher than that of single component or two-component. Consequently, the result indicates that the presence of multiple components in high-entropy materials leads to a complex electronic structure, resulting in the transfer of electrons from highly electronegative elements (such as O) to the 3d orbital of Ti, which increases the electron density around Ti and weakens the interaction between Ti and its ligand oxygen, thereby reducing the binding energy. The negative shift of Ti 2p orbital binding energy represents the generation of oxygen vacancies (Ov) in the catalyst, indicating that the catalyst exhibits better charge transfer activity for O2 [26,44]. Fig. 4 presents the O 1s spectra for the catalysts 0.1 Pt/TiO2, 0.1(PtM)/TiO2, and the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2. As illustrated in Figs. 4(a)–(f), the fitted curves reveal that the O 1s spectra for all catalysts are characterized by two predominant peaks: chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) at 529.6 ± 0.1 eV and lattice oxygen of TiO2 (Oβ) at 528.4 ± 0.1 eV. Notably, Oα exhibits greater migration activity compared to Oβ, attributed to the weaker oxygen bond, which enhances CO oxidation under atmospheric conditions. The calculated ratios of Oα/(Oα + Oβ) are as follows: 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 (14.8%) > 0.1(PtNi)/TiO2 (14.8%) > 0.1(PtMn)/TiO2 (8.3%) > 0.1Pt/TiO2 (7.9%) > 0.1(PtFe)/TiO2 (6.5%) > 0.1(PtCo)/TiO2 (4.7%). These results suggest that the high-entropy active component significantly enhances the surface adsorption of oxygen on the catalyst [45,46]. Typically, chemisorbed oxygen with lower bond energy contributes to improved catalytic activity for CO oxidation. The analysis of the Ti 2p spectrum depicted in Fig. 3 also indicates that the robust interaction between high-entropy components and TiO2 facilitates the transformation of lattice oxygen on the TiO2 surface into reactive oxygen species. In contrast to single or dual active components, high-entropy active components introduce a novel electron acquisition pathway for oxygen atoms within titanium dioxide. The synergistic interaction among various metal elements (Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) effectively modulates the electronic states between active metal sites and carriers, thereby enhancing electron transport from titanium to oxygen. The chemical valence state of the highly dispersed Pt element on the TiO2 surface was comprehensively assessed using Pt 4f spectrum. As illustrated in Fig. 5, among the six catalysts examined, the predominant valence states of Pt species are Pt2+ and Pt0. In comparison to the fresh 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst, the proportion of Pt0 in the 0.1(PtMn)/TiO2, 0.1(PtFe)/TiO2, and 0.1(PtCo)/TiO2 catalysts decreased from 47.5% to approximately 46.8%, 44.1%, and 32.9%, respectively. Conversely, the proportion of Pt0 in the 0.1(PtCo)/TiO2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts increased to 48.8% and 72.4%, respectively. Notably, in the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst, Pt0 constituted the majority of the content. Compared to the activation of the pure Pt element (47.3%), the high-entropy component resulted in a significantly larger proportion of Pt0 (60.5%), likely due to enhanced electronic interactions among the active metals, which facilitate charge exchange between Pt and other elements [47]. In the HECs, Pt exhibits the highest electronegativity. Consequently, the valence electron cloud density of the surrounding atoms, including Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, tends to be skewed towards the Pt atom, resulting in a reduction in its binding energy. Furthermore, the electron transfer among the polymetallic elements facilitates the modulation of electron exchange between Pt and the external atoms, leading to charge rearrangement and minor charge transfer. 3.4 Activity and stability of the catalyst The influence of various transition elements on the CO catalytic oxidation performance of a 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst was examined across different reaction temperatures, as depicted in Fig. 6 . The experimental data indicate that when distinct active components such as 0.1PtMn, 0.1PtFe, 0.1MnCo, 0.1PtNi, and 0.1PtMnFeCoNi are deposited on the TiO2 surface, the incorporation of minimal amounts of Fe and Co enables the catalyst to achieve complete CO conversion at 300 and 320 °C, respectively. This represents an increase of 30 and 50 °C in the complete conversion temperature compared to 0.1Pt/TiO2. In contrast, the introduction of Mn and Ni results in a complete conversion temperature of 270 °C, aligning with that of 0.1Pt/TiO2. Notably, when all four transition elements are simultaneously incorporated, a remarkable outcome is observed, with the complete conversion temperature of CO catalyzed by 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 decreasing to 230 °C. To further validate the enhancement depicted in Fig. 6(a) of multi-active components, the impact of active components with a 0.1(1Pt4M) loading on CO reactivity was investigated (Fig. 6(b)). The experimental results indicate that increasing the content of Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni enhances the CO catalytic activity of 0.1(1Pt4M)/TiO2 compared to 0.1(PtM)/TiO2. Notably, the CO conversion rates for 0.1(1Pt4Mn)/TiO2 and 0.1(1Pt4Fe)/TiO2 catalysts reached 100% at a reaction temperature of 250 °C, although they did not surpass the performance of 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2. These findings demonstrate that the catalyst supported on a high-entropy active component exhibits superior CO catalytic oxidation performance, achieving a 100% CO conversion rate at 230 °C even with ultra-low Pt loading. To further assess the catalytic performance of 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 for CO oxidation, its tolerance to H2O and SO2 was evaluated, with the findings presented in Fig. 6(c). The data indicate that in the presence of H2O and a combination of H2O and SO2 in the atmosphere, the catalyst maintains complete conversion at 230 °C. Conversely, when only SO2 is present in the flue gas, the catalytic oxidation efficiency for CO decreases to 80%. Notably, the introduction of H2O restores the catalytic activity. These findings suggest that 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 exhibits substantial stability in complex flue gas environments. The presence of H2O in the flue gas enhances the CO catalytic activity, while SO2 and CO exhibit competitive adsorption on the catalyst surface. Importantly, the promotional effect of H2O surpasses the inhibitory effect of SO2. 3.5 In-situ DRIFTS experiment The catalytic oxidation mechanism of CO on the surfaces of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts was examined using in-situ DRIFTs spectra. The study elucidated the detailed reaction pathway of CO on the surface of high-entropy catalysts. Figs. 7(a) and 7(d) present the instantaneous changes adsorption spectra of CO on the surfaces of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts at 250 °C, respectively. Within 30 min of CO introduction into the system, both catalysts exhibited CO adsorption signals at 2084 and 2158 cm–1. Notably, the adsorption strength of CO on the surface of the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst was significantly greater than that on the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, at 13 min following CO introduction, the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst generated carbonate species at 1102, 1283, and 1463 cm–1, suggests that the lattice oxygen in the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst reacted with a small quantity of CO to form CO3 2– [48,49,50]. Similarly, the CO+O2 atmosphere was introduced into the system at 250 °C, with the results presented in Figs. 7(b) and (d). It is evident that the introduction of O2 results in the appearance of characteristic peaks of CO and CO3 2– on the catalyst surface, particularly the stretching vibration peaks of monodentate and bidentate carbonates within the 1250–1800 cm–1 range [51–53]. Notably, within the spectral range, the CO3 2– peak intensity for the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst is significantly higher compared to that of the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst. The difference is primarily attributed to the fact that the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst completely catalyzes CO at 230 °C, whereas the complete catalytic temperature for the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst is 270 °C. As CO2 is produced, the CO3 2– species on the catalyst surface decompose. The findings indicate that CO initially reacts with lattice oxygen on the surface of the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst, generating oxygen vacancies that are subsequently replenished by atmospheric O2. Carbonates are consumed to form CO2 as dictated by reaction equilibrium. Consequently, the catalytic oxidation of CO over the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst adheres to the Mars-van Krevelen (M-vK) mechanism [54,55]. Furthermore, the reaction pathways of CO + O2 on the surfaces of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts were comprehensively investigated across various temperatures. The findings are presented in Figs. 7(c) and 7(f). Notably, when the temperature is below the complete conversion threshold of CO on the catalyst, spectra for both 0.1Pt/TiO2 and high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 exhibit peaks corresponding to CO adsorption and carbonate formation. As the temperature increases, the peak intensities of CO and CO3 2– on the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 surface gradually diminish and stabilize, with a CO2 formation peak emerging at 2300–2400 cm–1. In contrast, the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst displays a CO2 formation peak at temperatures significantly below the complete conversion temperature (225 °C), whereas the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst shows a CO2 formation peak at approximately 230 °C. The result suggests that the presence of O2 in the atmosphere is crucial for the catalytic activity of the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst, while temperature serves as the limiting factor for the catalytic efficiency of the high-entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst. More interestingly, even if the operating temperature of the 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst reaches 270 °C, there are still a large number of carbonates on the surface. Obviously, the catalytic oxidation mechanism of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and high entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts for CO is inconsistent, indicating that the mechanism of 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalyst for CO follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [56,57]. 3.6 DFT calculation The reaction mechanism of CO on the surface of high entropy 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst is still lack of key introduction. In order to understand the CO oxidation process at the atomic level, the adsorption of CO and O2 on the catalyst surface is calculated by DFT. Specifically, according to the TEM and XRD structure, TiO2 is mainly set to anatase 101 model. The optimized structure 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 were shown in Fig. S9. And the adsorption energy of CO and O2 on the surface of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts were also calculated. As shown in Figs. 8(a)–(h) , the adsorption energies (E ads) of CO and O2 on the 0.1Pt/TiO2 are –1.48 and –1.20 eV, respectively, which are much lower than those on the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 surface (–1.65 and –1.72 eV). The results indicates that the high-entropy component can optimize the active site structure of the catalyst and promote the adsorption and conversion of CO and O2 at various metal sites. Furthermore, the Bader-charge analyses were carried out to corroborate the improved performance. As shown in Figs. 8(b), (d), (f) and (h), more electrons are transferred from the surface of 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst to gas molecules (CO and O2), indicating that CO and O2 molecules are more easily converted into CO* and O* in the high-entropy system. A large number of charge interactions between the active components and TiO2 lead to the lattice distortion, which is conducive to the transfer of electrons in the catalyst system and thus improves the oxidation activity. The more active metal atoms exposed on the surface of the high-entropy active component can have a strong coordination effect with the O on the surface of TiO2. The introduction of high-entropy active components increases the local electron density on the surface of titanium dioxide, which promoting the electron dispersion phenomenon on the surface of 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst. Through realizing the filling of metal interstitial electrons to the sub-interstitial state of TiO2 to promote the activation of lattice oxygen in TiO2, thereby strengthening the SMSI between high-entropy components and TiO2 support and promoting the adsorption of CO and O2. On this basis, the projected partial density of states (PDOS) of all the elements of 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 were understood in detail, as shown in Figs. 8(i) and (g). In particular, the overlap between the d orbitals of Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Ti, indicates a strong interaction between the active component and the support. Obviously, Fig. 8(i) showed that Pt atom is the main active center in 0.1Pt/TiO2. However, the high-entropy system changes the 3d orbital of Ti, and TiO2 transforms from semiconductor properties to metal properties (Fig. 8(j)). The analysis presented in Fig. 8(g) indicates that the higher energy range (–7––5 eV) is predominantly characterized by Fe 3d and Mn 3d orbitals, whereas the lower energy range (–2.5–0 eV) is primarily influenced by Pt 4f and Ni 3d orbitals. The distribution facilitates the alignment of the TiO2‘s orbital electrons closer to the Fermi level (E f = 0 eV), thereby enabling effective electron transfer. Transition metals such as Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni possess a substantial number of vacant d orbitals and unpaired electrons, which contribute to both d-d and d-p orbital hybridizations. The incorporation of Pt, characterized by a narrow Fermi level and high electron density of states, enhances d-p orbital hybridization. The enhancement increases the likelihood of charge transfer and bonding interactions between high-entropy active components and CO molecules, thereby significantly augmenting the catalytic activity [58]. The introduction of high–entropy components in the TiO2 crystal structure causes local field distortion, triggering the transition of the 3d orbital of Ti from a singlet low-spin state to a stable triplet state, generating a free electron capture center, and optimizing the electronic band structure. The dual active centers of heteroatoms and oxygen vacancies promote the electron transfer between the adsorbent and the adsorbate, and increase the adsorption energy of CO and O2 [25,59,60]. Because the conversion of CO intermediates plays a major role in the oxidation process, the number of electrons transferred from CO to the catalyst induced by the high-entropy active component is significantly higher than that of the single Pt element, resulting in significant charge accumulation, which supports the mutual promotion between CO and O2 and 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst, and explains the M-vK mechanism in the CO oxidation process catalyzed by the 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalyst interface [61,62]. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have proposed a convenient method for the synthesis of ultra-low doping 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 high entropy catalyst with SMSI to achieve efficient CO catalytic oxidation. Compared with 0.1Pt/TiO2 and 0.1(Pt-M)/TiO2 catalysts, 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 exhibits excellent catalytic behavior for CO oxidation, being an industrial catalytic material with potential application prospects. In particular, he introduction of high-entropy component reduces the complete conversion temperature (T 100) of CO from 270 to 230 °C. Through experiments and DFT calculations, it is clear that the strong synergy between high-entropy component and TiO2 promotes the adsorption of CO and O2 molecules on the catalyst surface and significantly optimizes the electronic structure of different elements in the catalyst. The results of in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations further indicate that the M-vK mechanism plays a crucial role in the catalytic oxidation of CO by 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2. The strategy of ultra-low-loading high-entropy component catalysts will help inspire the design and production of efficient and inexpensive industrial flue gas CO catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The catalyst cost is a key factor limiting the CO purification of sintering flue gas. Here, an ultra-low-loading high-entropy catalyst was prepared by simple calcination process. By anchoring multiple active metal sites in the stable anatase TiO2 phase, it shows efficient CO catalytic oxidation activity. The metal components (Pt, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) were uniformly dispersed on the surface of TiO2 in the form of high-entropy compounds and undergo strong metal and support interaction with TiO2. The results showed that 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 achieved complete oxidation of CO at 230 °C, and its catalytic oxidation ability was significantly better than that of the corresponding monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. The high-entropy component adjusts the electronic environment between the TiO2 support and the metal to promote the reduction of the Ti3d band gap, enhances the electron-induced ability of the catalytic system to gas molecules (CO and O2), and exhibits excellent resistance to SO2 and H2O. The work is of great significance to understand the synergistic regulation of catalyst activity by multiple metal at the atomic level and provides a strategy for effectively reducing the content of precious metals in the catalyst.

coredata.dc:title: Ultra-low doping 0.1(PtMnFeCoNi)/TiO2 catalysts: Modulating the electronic states of active metal sites to enhance CO oxidation through high entropy strategy
